linkTarget.anchoringText: This work involves two large unconventional formations in the WCSB: the Montney (Figure 1a) and East Duvernay (Figure 1b) formations. The Montney Formation is Lower Triassic in age and is bound by the overlying Doig and underlying Belloy Formations. The Duvernay Formation is overlain by the grey shales of the Ireton Formation and overlies the Cooking Lake or Majeau Lake Formations. Although both formations are considered in the traditional sense to be "shales," they have vastly different compositions and physical properties; thus, their interactions with fluids are not the same.

This work involves two large unconventional formations in the WCSB: the Montney (Figure 1a) and East Duvernay (Figure 1b) formations. The Montney Formation is Lower Triassic in age and is bound by the overlying Doig and underlying Belloy Formations. The Duvernay Formation is overlain by the grey shales of the Ireton Formation and overlies the Cooking Lake or Majeau Lake Formations. Although both formations are considered in the traditional sense to be "shales," they have vastly different compositions and physical properties; thus, their interactions with fluids are not the same.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1b
image-wrap.caption: East Duvernay formation (AER/AGS Open File Report 2017-02).

formatted-caption.caption-text: East Duvernay formation (AER/AGS Open File Report 2017-02).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The surfactant with the lowest surface tension does not necessarily yield the lowest interfacial tension with oil. The interfacial tension represents the fluid-fluid interaction between the surfactant solution and the oil; therefore, different oils exhibit different interfacial tensions with the same surfactant solution. The results of the interfacial tension analysis were combined with those from the Amott oil recovery tests (Figures 2a and 2b). Amott test results were normalized against the highest performing surfactant, which was MFS in both cases.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2a
image-wrap.caption: Amott oil recovery and interfacial tension (IFT) using Montney oil and rock.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Amott oil recovery and interfacial tension (IFT) using Montney oil and rock.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The surfactant with the lowest surface tension does not necessarily yield the lowest interfacial tension with oil. The interfacial tension represents the fluid-fluid interaction between the surfactant solution and the oil; therefore, different oils exhibit different interfacial tensions with the same surfactant solution. The results of the interfacial tension analysis were combined with those from the Amott oil recovery tests (Figures 2a and 2b). Amott test results were normalized against the highest performing surfactant, which was MFS in both cases.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2b
image-wrap.caption: Amott oil recovery and interfacial tension (IFT) using East Duvernay oil and rock.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Amott oil recovery and interfacial tension (IFT) using East Duvernay oil and rock.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The rate of water decline is assumed to be controlled by the effect of relative permeability. Fu (2018) recorded flowback rates and pressure data from a Woodford well (Figure 3a) and compared the harmonic-decline semi-log plot (Figure 3b) of water and gas rate versus cumulative water production (Cum Wtr) during immediate flowback and post-flowback periods. The trendline in the semi-log plot of water rate and Cum Wtr after hydrocarbon breakthrough estimates the ULFR. As shown in Figure 3b, hydrocarbon gas rates are typically observed to remain relatively steady as the water rate declines harmonically.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3a
image-wrap.caption: Woodford well flowback rates (Fu, et al., 2018).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Woodford well flowback rates (Fu, et al., 2018).

linkTarget.bib:
Dehghanpour et al., 2018

The trendline in the semi-log plot of water rate and Cum Wtr after hydrocarbon breakthrough estimates the ULFR. As shown in Figure 3b, hydrocarbon gas rates are typically observed to remain relatively steady as the water rate declines harmonically.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The rate and pressure data from the post-frac gelled oil frac flow and buildup test is shown in Figure 4a. The log-log plot suggests a reasonable permeability of 0.13 mD. Fracture linear flow is also apparent and the effective fracture half-length is only 8 m, assuming all 18 stages were effective (Figure 4b).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4a
image-wrap.caption: Rate and pressure data for an 18-stage gelled oil frac in the Montney.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Rate and pressure data for an 18-stage gelled oil frac in the Montney.

Fracture linear flow is also apparent and the effective fracture half-length is only 8 m, assuming all 18 stages were effective (Figure 4b).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4b
image-wrap.caption: Estimation of well permeability for the 18-stage gelled oil frac in the Montney.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Estimation of well permeability for the 18-stage gelled oil frac in the Montney.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Although pressure transient analyses (PTA) are extremely helpful in characterizing well performance, understanding the rock-fluid interaction requires the use of other diagnostic plotting techniques. Again, we turn to the simple but novel harmonic-decline semi-log plot. The flowback oil rate versus flowback cumulative oil (Cum Oil) and gas rate versus flowback Cum Oil are plotted in Figure 5. By extrapolating the decline of the oil rate along the x-axis, the maximum load fluid recovery can be estimated.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Gas production and gelled oil flowback for the 18-stage gelled oil frac in the Montney.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Gas production and gelled oil flowback for the 18-stage gelled oil frac in the Montney.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6a
image-wrap.caption: Water, gas and condensate production rates versus cumulative water production for the MFS frac in the Montney.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water, gas and condensate production rates versus cumulative water production for the MFS frac in the Montney.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The harmonic decline semi-log plot of water, gas and condensate rates vs Cum Wtr (load fluid) is shown in Figure 7a. Although the data are limited, the gas had to be restricted to 150E3 m3/d during the flowback operation after having recovered only 15% of the load fluid. Figure 6b shows the same data represented by a Cartesian plot of Cum Hydrocarbon Gas and Oil versus Cum Water. The sharp gas break at approximately 4000 m3 (or 15% load fluid recovery) represents the moment the operator restricted the gas rate.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6b
image-wrap.caption: Cumulative oil and gas production versus cumulative water production for the MFS frac in the Montney.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cumulative oil and gas production versus cumulative water production for the MFS frac in the Montney.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The harmonic decline semi-log plot of water, gas and condensate rates vs Cum Wtr (load fluid) is shown in Figure 7a. Although the data are limited, the gas had to be restricted to 150E3 m3/d during the flowback operation after having recovered only 15% of the load fluid. Figure 6b shows the same data represented by a Cartesian plot of Cum Hydrocarbon Gas and Oil versus Cum Water. The sharp gas break at approximately 4000 m3 (or 15% load fluid recovery) represents the moment the operator restricted the gas rate.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7a
image-wrap.caption: Cumulative oil production versus cumulative load fluid recovery for the Duvernay well.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cumulative oil production versus cumulative load fluid recovery for the Duvernay well.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 7a depicts the Cum Oil produced from an 11-stage "plug'n perf" well in the Duvernay formation. The well was initially designed for 24 stages but the remaining stages were not completed due to mechanical liner issues. The well was subsequently shut-in for 201 days for evaluation purposes. During the initial 11 stages, 13,742 m3 of water was pumped using a weak surfactant (NE) at a loading of 1.0 L/m3. Since formations such as the Duvernay have low irreducible water saturation and do not exhibit mobile water, as load fluid recovery increases, the hydrocarbon curve should approach a vertical asymptote. In this well, water blockage appears to have limited the oil production of the well. Injecting the water with NE provided only a moderate reduction in IFT, resulting in poor hydrocarbon production and load fluid recovery (Figure 7b).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7b
image-wrap.caption: Estimation of the total load fluid recovery for the Duvernay well.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Estimation of the total load fluid recovery for the Duvernay well.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Early in the development of the East Duvernay, some level of surfactant loading was deemed necessary to complete the large volumes of slick water treatments required for enhanced oil recovery from this nanodarcy, oil-wet formation. Figure 8 shows a Cartesian plot of multiple wells completed in the Eastern Duvernay Basin treated with different surfactants ranging from microemulsions (ME) to non-emulsifiers (NE). The plot compares Cumulative Load Fluid Recovery to Cumulative Hydrocarbon Liquid Production. The stage count between wells varied from 12 stages during early development to beyond 40 stages in later years.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Comparative results of 10 wells in the Eastern Duvernay Basin completed with different surfactants by plotting Cum Load plotted against Hydrocarbon liquid cumulative production.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparative results of 10 wells in the Eastern Duvernay Basin completed with different surfactants by plotting Cum Load plotted against Hydrocarbon liquid cumulative production.
